summary: Rolando Masferrer was a Cuban exile and former senator involved in various activities against the governments of Cuba and Haiti. The documents suggest he was a significant figure in anti-Castro and anti-Duvalier movements, organizing groups of exiles in Miami to potentially invade Haiti. He had connections to former Batista officers, Marquez Sterling, and possibly the CIA. The documents span from 1959 to 1976, indicating a long period of involvement in these activities. There are also mentions of investigations into his possible connections with other individuals and activities in the Cuban exile community, as well as allegations of CIA involvement in his assassination.
significance: While the documents do not explicitly link Rolando Masferrer to the JFK assassination, his involvement in anti-Castro activities and connections to the CIA, as well as his presence in the Cuban exile community, place him within the broader context of individuals and groups that have been scrutinized in relation to the assassination. The documents suggest he was a person of interest to U.S. intelligence agencies and the FBI, particularly due to his activities against foreign governments and potential connections to other individuals of interest.
